content:
Last Edit: 2023-11-15


Here are some good tutorials/articles/blogs that I found useful in my study and programming.

Backend

[Tutorial] [Notes] Authentication on the web. JWT, session, cookie, XSS, CSRF…

[Tutorial] System Design Interview with AWS. Design Youtube, Whatsapp, Twitter.

[SITE] Full stack web dev reference site. It has code example for any combo you want, e.g. Springboot+React, Django+Vue… Not comprehensive tutorials but definitely sufficient to create a runnable tech stack rapidly for testing purposes.

[ARTICLE] Client-side rendering VS server-side rendering


Machine Learning/Data

[ARTICLE] An in-depth explanation about bias and variance.

[ARTICLE] Importance of normalising data in neural networks.Â 

[TUTORIAL] The best series of introductory videos for neural networks. Mainly talked about MLP.

[COURSE] University of Columbia’s full Computer Vision course. Exceptionally well structured and delivered. Legendary professor.

[ARTICLE] Feature visualization and how convolutional neural network learns

[SITE] A pre-trained CNN playground. You can use different pre-trained CNN as feature extractors. Then use extracted embeddings to perform Sementic Search - find another similar image within a dataset. There are many adjustable parameters, including datasets, pre-trained CNN, which layer you want to use, and distance metrics. Pretty fun to play around.


Computer Networks

[TUTORIAL] Computer network tutorials. I like his presentation style.

[ARTICLE] What happens when you access a website? Explain all OSI layers’ behaviour from the physical layer to the application layer.

[SITE] Visualise and let you play with TCP’s retransmission. Helpful to the exam.


Artifical Intelligence (The subject)

The Artificial Intelligence University subject (not AI in general sense). E.g. search algorithms, game agent, CSP, bayesian net…

[TUTORIAL] This professor is truly a legend. Helped me so much for the exam. You can find step-by-step demo for all search algorithms, MCTS and constrain-satisfication.

[SITE] Minimax and alpha-beta pruning simulator. For the exam purpose, randomly make some trees by yourself and perform the pruning and backpropagations to practice.

[COURSE] Berkeley’s Artificial Intelligence course.


Distributed Systems

[COURSE] MIT’s Distributed Systems. Most reputable yet challenging Distributed System course. It introduces a new middleware technology every module. But it heavily depends on your self-learning skills, as you need to read the original papers before watching the lectures. If you also feel sad taking Unimelb’s ill-designed trash course COMP90015 (Distributed Systems) that 40% of the contents overlap with COMP30023, 60% of the contents are too high-level and old AF, then consider self-studying this. Or you can use the syllabus here as a guide and watch other tutorials.


Cryptography

[TUTORIAL] Tutorial for finite field (Galois field). This channel also has many good math tutorials. This video is especially helpful if you are a Unimelb student taking COMP90043 (Crytography and Security) - The subject content on the finite field part is so ill-designed. The lecture slides are nothing but a stacking of formula with no connections. Plus if your lecturer is Udaya then… (Other than these, the subject is pretty good)

[COURSE] Crytography and Network Security full course. Might be helpful to your COMP90043 study. But I find the suggested textbook (Crytography and Network Security - William Stallings) more useful for this subject. The subject syllabus follows the textbook exactly so if you didn’t understand anything just refer to the textbook.
description: Some good tutorials/articles/blogs that I found useful in my study and programming.
title: Good Tech Tutorials/Blogs/Sites
